boat.name: Wender
boat.full_description:
'Wender' was probably built as a dayboat to a design by GF Holmes. Holmes was an East Coast man who worked in close communicaton with Albert Strange so it remains obscure as to why she has Morecambe Bay Prawner features. In her 1890s form she had a low cuddy forward of a long nobby cockpit. She was laid up at Menai Bridge during the First World War.

After the war she spent most of her time before 1939 owned by Mr King who sailed her out of Caernarfon, when he died in the late 1930s he willed 'Wender' to two sisters who left her with Dickie's of Bangor for the duration of the Second World War.

She was discovered there by H.R. Davies in a poor condition. He bought her for £55 and with a friend Mr Hughes had Dickie's work on her. They got 'Wender' back sailing but then with family committemnts sold her to a Welshman who sailed the Irish Sea.

Her next owner was Peter Bunting who found her laid up in Arklow. He cruised her with a growning family. To improve the accommodation they lenghthened the coachroof. The next owner was Victor Fusco who cruised her from Strangford Lough for many years.

Sam Poole boought her in 1971 and has cruised many many miles with his wife Sue and their two sons.
boat.construction_details: Pitch pine on oak, Teak upper, long fin keel lead ballast keel.
boat.short_description: Built initially as a dayboat, Wender has low freeboard but has cruised thousands of miles.
